Not Really for the Quitting: The Darker Side of Vaping

18/11/2022

Henry Gee (he/him) reflects on the present vaping market and its targeting of younger audiences

Image by Rafael Barros

By Katy Leverett

IÂ used to be a smoker. Not a heavy smoker,Â only a couple a day, but enough to where Iâ€™dÂ be planning out my time so as to fit roughlyÂ around when I knew it was likely that I wouldÂ need another cigarette. â€œIt gets me outsideâ€ Iâ€™dÂ say whenever a friend gave me a questioningÂ look as they saw me standing by the backdoorÂ shivering in the winter sun. â€œIt helps regulateÂ my breathingâ€ I say turning away to cough upÂ phlegm from deep within my lungs. â€œItâ€™s a nightÂ out, everyone smokes on a night outâ€ said toÂ strangers, not smoking, in the queue for Flares.

When I was quitting, I decided to forgoÂ any form of nicotine altogether. No vape, noÂ patches, no gum, absolutely nothing. I assumedÂ it would be quicker; flush the nicotine out of myÂ body and be done with the whole thing. It wasÂ the summer, so I thought the warmer weatherÂ would help with the shakes, and the sunlightÂ would boost my serotonin levels making me lessÂ angry and irritable.

That wasnâ€™t quite what ended up happening. I was a right arsehole that entire summer, aÂ proper sourpuss. It didnâ€™t help that Boris Johnson was in the final stages of imploding as PM,Â but it at least gave me something to think aboutÂ other than the thing I was trying hard to notÂ think about.

Coming back to university, I had assumedÂ the day-to-day would be the hardest. OutsideÂ of the chemical dependence on nicotine, theÂ hardest thing to overcome about addiction isÂ the routine. The tactile feeling of the cigaretteÂ between your fingers; the motion of bringing itÂ to your lips; the lighter that wonâ€™t light becauseÂ of a worn-out spark wheel; breathing in theÂ smoke, holding, and exhaling.

These are the things that a patch or gumÂ simply cannot replicate. Trying to re-form aÂ routine that didnâ€™t revolve around these ritualsÂ and smoke breaks seemed incredibly daunting.Â (I hasten to add that while that above description of the routine may have sounded strangelyÂ romantic, the reality is that smoking, and addiction are very boring. It only seems enticing andÂ romantic because as soon as itâ€™s over youâ€™re already looking forward to the next and lookingÂ back nostalgically at the one you just finished).

As it turned out, for me, forming new habits wasnâ€™t too bad. As long as I reminded myselfÂ to go outside every so often for a break or aÂ walk, I was okay. Addictions, however mild, areÂ all consuming, and itâ€™s easy to forget that there was a time before you started smoking. Forming new routines was easy because, obviously,Â Iâ€™d been not smoking for more of my life than IÂ had! It took quitting to see just how much effortÂ it took, both physically and mentally, to keepÂ up the addiction. Realising the amount of freeÂ time and free mental space I now had becauseÂ I wasnâ€™t having to constantly think about smoking made life a lot easier.

The problems arose when it came to nightsÂ out; I had been smoking for as long as Iâ€™d beenÂ going out-out. Going outside for some freshÂ air and not smoking just felt wrong. DespiteÂ the fact that most people who step outside forÂ respite from the sweating, writhing hoards areÂ non-smokers, (who get, rightly, very annoyedÂ when you interrupt their scheduled cool downÂ by blowing cancer fog into their faces), it alwaysÂ felt like something was missing. The routine;Â the nostalgic, neurotic routine was missing.

So instead of buying a pack of cigarettesÂ â€˜only for nights outâ€™, because that is totally whatÂ I would use it for, I bought a disposable vape forÂ a fiver and at the end of the night threw it away.Â It seemed to work. Then I realised how stupid IÂ looked. Then how sickening I smelt whilst looking stupid. Then I stopped all together.

Whatâ€™s the point of allÂ that, I hear you cry, other than to fill up theÂ required wordÂ count, youÂ lazy hack!Â Frankly,Â bit rude, tone it down. ItÂ was something I neededÂ to get off my chest.Â To admit to myself howÂ awful my former habit was, andÂ remind myself that Iâ€™ve made the rightÂ decision. Big Tobacco doesnâ€™t need any moreÂ of my money, nor do they deserve it. Itâ€™s alsoÂ where vapes come in.

Although I mostly quit without the useÂ of a vape, when I needed one to replicate thatÂ routine of smoking without nearly as much ofÂ the risk, I was glad that there was a product thatÂ could accommodate these needs. In a recentÂ vaping evidence review conducted by PublicÂ Health England (PHE), they found that all evidence suggested that vaping posed â€œa small fraction of the risks of smokingâ€ (in the short andÂ medium term), thus lowering the risks of highÂ blood pressure, cardiac arrest, and cancer. ThatÂ same review also points out that smokers whoÂ used vapes as a quitting-aid had a higher chanceÂ of success and were less likely to relapse.

I think this is where vapes are most useful:Â a quitting-aid that replicates the rituals of smoking, with far less of the harmful side-effects.Â And if that was all vaping was, then IÂ wouldnâ€™t have any problem with it. The factÂ that vapes arenâ€™t currently available throughÂ the NHS doesnâ€™t at all undermine their roleÂ as merely quitting aids. So, in a surprise twistÂ that is a surprise to literally no one, the tobaccoÂ companies that profit off of people continuingÂ to use their tobacco products, donâ€™t actuallyÂ want people to stop using tobacco products. Iâ€™llÂ come back to this.

Looking to the PHE review, whilst vapingÂ use among adults has remained steady over recent years, the number of young people vapingÂ has doubled in the past year alone and is expected to rise further in the future. (On a sideÂ note, despite the report calling them young people, given the age range theyâ€™re talking about,Â 11-18, Iâ€™m going to call them whatÂ they are â€“ children).Â Some chalk this upÂ to a broaderÂ cultural migration in the West towards vaping, and childrenÂ who would normally take up smoking are instead taking upÂ vaping. To be honest, I simply donâ€™tÂ buy it. These kinds of explanations make assumptions that, according to the data, simplyÂ arenâ€™t true; and they canâ€™t account for the recentÂ increase.

To me - itâ€™s simple. Well, kind of. SmokingÂ is an expensive habit because of taxation. Vaping is an expensive habit because of do-hickiys.Â The tank costs money, the battery costs money,Â the refills cost money, and if it breaks, you haveÂ to buy all of these again. Enter disposable vapes,Â to a collective boo and hiss from the audience.Â Of all children vaping, over 50 percent now useÂ disposable vapes, up from only five percent twoÂ years ago. They are cheap, often less than a fiver,Â and far easier to come by. They arenâ€™t subjectÂ to the same plain packaging laws as cigarettes,Â donâ€™t have to be hidden from sight in retailers,Â and as a friend recently pointed out to me; areÂ often sold directly next to sweets â€“ possibly inÂ an attempt to target a similar demographic.

Now, I am not saying that these tobaccoÂ companies are deliberately advertising theirÂ cheap, colourful, sweet, flavoured disposableÂ vapes to children. That is still against the law.Â In the UK, vaping products still come underÂ the same restrictions regarding advertising inÂ traditional media and in public as cigarettes.Â But children tend not to consume traditionalÂ forms of media, instead getting their in-formation and entertainment from the inter-net. The regulation of social media posts is farÂ murkier, and tobacco companies have taken fullÂ advantage of this loophole.

The law states that "direct person-to-person communicationsâ€ are exempt from regulation. This includes posts on social media. ByÂ sponsoring influencers on various platforms,Â tobacco companies can effectively advertiseÂ their products to anyone, anywhere, with noÂ restrictions.

According to a report inÂ The Guardian, a lot of these posts are directed towardsÂ children. Overwhelmingly, the audiences ofÂ influencers who post this sponsored contentÂ skew younger. Posts tend to emphasise theÂ vape's playful, colourful, youthful aesthetics, and repeatedly emphasise how cheap andÂ readily available they are.

Despite being less likely to lead to theÂ same terrible side-effects as smoking, vaping isÂ not without its risks. The PHE report is carefulÂ to emphasise this. There are currently no studies into the long-term effects of vaping, and asÂ stated above, we only know that they cause lessÂ of the side-effects associated with smoking. WeÂ donâ€™t know what side effects they cause on theirÂ own because this is not the research that is being done. If vapes continue to be seen solely asÂ a quitting-aid (and not as something separate),Â we will never know the effects they may haveÂ until itâ€™s too late. The tobacco companies knewÂ smoking caused cancer back in the fifties andÂ did nothing for fear of losing profits. Just saying. History does not repeat itself, but it oftenÂ rhymes.

Last year, the six biggest tobacco companies were collectively valued at over 360 billionÂ US dollars (statista.com), and made over $50Â billion in profit during 2018, the last year whenÂ figures were released. This number is only expected to have increased since this point.

Big Tobacco, under the guise of helpingÂ smokers quit, is flooding the market with cheapÂ vapes advertised to children. This increasesÂ their profit margins, keeps their investors happy, and gives board members huge bonuses. NoÂ one wants or expects to seen young people putÂ at such risk. Frankly, itâ€™s disgusting and shameful how weâ€™ve all been deceived. Then again,Â why we ever thought that large corporationsÂ would invest in a product that would activelyÂ encourage people to stop using their productsÂ was perhaps a little short sighted.
